history.content: I personally (along with I think many other students here) would HIGHLY advise against taking any of the CS61_ series classes together. Theres no rush in taking them and both 61B and 61C have pretty intense workloads no matter how good you are at programming. 61C does C for a little bit but is definitely not a C++ programming class. 61B is also one of the most important CS classes you will take at Cal so it can only benefit you to have more time with the material.

children.subject:
Yes, I would definitely second what anon said. Seems kind of silly to me to take all 3 concurrently - you gain practically nothing from zooming through them, but compromise on quality of how much you learn.

You would also be compromising on time you have to spend on other things, like clubs, friends, research, or just personal interests and projects, which as a senior looking back, is honestly even more valuable/worthwhile than classes sometimes.

You would get much more out of putting off 61C for a different semester and spending more time on 61B material and learning it inside and out. That class really sets you up for success as a programmer (whether it is for writing your own stuff, or for doing well in interviews).

I don't think this would be a very fun schedule (too much programming and not enough psets imo), but I do think it's doable. I found 16a pretty easy (and I took it without lin alg experience.) With a class in linear algebra, the first third and the last few weeks of the class should be very easy. If you've done competitive programming (i.e. USACO) before, Hug's 61b at least would likely be a breeze for you. Hilfinger's is more project-dependent, and I'm not entirely sure how the workload compares, but you'll probably have less of an edge.

I'm taking 61c next semester so I can't say much on that front, but I've heard from friends that Garcia's version is in the same ballpark of workload as 61b. 

Personally, I'd recommend dropping 61c for 70 if you haven't taken it already. 16a/61b/70 is doable and seems like a more enjoyable courseload for me, though your opinion may differ depending on how much you like/dislike math.
I'm currently in 61B and 61C currently, and its quite doable--there is minimal overlap.

history.content:
So I am taking these three classes together next semester, and I'm not entirely sure if it's a good idea. For background, I did competitive programming in C++ and Java and did well in them and I have taken a linear algebra class before. However, is the workload of these classes concurrently too much?

Thanks!
history.subject: 61B, 61C, 16A
